message:
After almost two days of Android training. I don't really like it.
It has some nice ideas but mostly poorly executed compared to .NET, WPF, and Windows Phone for example.
Is that true or is it just a bad first impression?

data.message:
poorly executed بمعنى إيه؟
بشكل عام كمبرمج ميكروسوفتاوي طول عمري كل لما باشوف أي منصة تانية بابقى عايز أرجع، وبادعي ربنا إن ميكروسوفت تشد حيلها وترجع زي زمان علشان مانضطرش نغوص في العك والسيولة الطائشة اللي في المنصات التانية

حسيت برده نفس الاحساس في الاول بس برجع وبقول اكيد انا غلطان عشان لو كان سئ للدرجة دي ماكنش هيكون ليه كل الشعبية دي ونلاقي عليه تطبيقات جبارة زي ما بنشوف , وبحاول اقنع نفسي اني كنت عايش في بيئة راقية زي الدوت نت ولما بطلع منها لأي مكان تاني أكيد هعاني لأني مش متعود على نظام العيشة هناك ماشية ازاي عشان اتعودت على الرفاهية المطلقة.
I had a similar feeling too, but honestly I haven't spent that much time working on Android. so I think it is more of comfort zone problem.

Visual Studio is the best IDE; Period.
However, as a platform, Android is very mature and got tons of API opened for devs, not like iOS or WindowsPhone
في الآخر هي كلها مسائل نسبية

my viewpoint will stick to devs
Android :open platform-over well engineered language (frankly sometimes overengineered) java - feature rich, simple and fast IDE 
.Net:closed/proprietary platform- over languages dependent merely and almost on idioms C#,VB - feature rich but hard and slow  hardware intensive IDE

مثال علي الـpoor execution (معلهش هأكتب بالإنجليزي شوية)
you can have id for views (controls) and you can get the control by findViewById method which is great
However, the name of the id is global to the app which can lead to conflicts if you have more than one developer
The only way to get a list of IDs is to compile the app and look at the compiled code
The way to avoid conflicts is to come up with a convention to avoid conflicts
The other thing related to this is that you find a control by name, I haven't seen a way to reach a control in a strongly-types way like this C# code
myForm.myControl
in Android, it seems to be like
ListView listView = (ListView)findViewById("myListView"); a
Note: Ignore that 'a' at the end, it's for formatting

Same thing goes for what seems like WPF (or more like markup to build UIs), all the ideas are there but not as well done as WPF

Here's a dumb questions but I really haven't seen this before:
Does Java not have properties for objects/classes?
Because everything is in getValue and setValue methods.
And events too. It's like OnSomeEvent method
Am I missing something?
Java doesn't have neither properties nor events
Wow, I can't believe I've went so far as a developer without knowing that.
Even generics in Java is half assed. It is just a compiler syntax sugar the bytecode doesn't know anything about Generics.

ماعرفش أندرويد لكن حاجه زي setValue و getValue كانت موجودة في السيلفرلايت علشان الأوبجكتات اللي تخص الـ UI اللي فيها animation و databinding والخ، كنت بتكتب مثلا
SetValue(MyControl.BackgroundColour, Red)
بدلا من 
MyControl.BackgroundColour = Red

بس عموما فهمت قصدك، وده كان قصدي برضو، تحس بشكل عام كأنك بتستخدم منتجات كلها beta أو تجارب!

Android is an operating system(Embedded Linux), I do not know why some of the comments compare it to .NET Framework. What Android as a developer should give you is the GUI layer, access to peripherals thru its API,..etc. Most phones 90% that runs windowsphone, android, iOS, they are based on ARM CPUs, they just differ in the OS Layer, IMHO, there are no big differences between all the OSes for developers. Languages differ, yes, but they are all the same from APIs point of view.  You can even write Android software using C++, and just use their GUI library using Java interfaces.

لكن حتي لو الكنترول له set methods برضه بيكون له خاصية property
سبب المشكلة زي ما محمد قال إن جافا مفيهاش خصائص زي الدوت نت
Ahmed Saleh كلامك مضبوط إني لخبطت بين أندرويد وجافا .. أنا قصدي المقارنة بين أندرويد وويندز فون أو جافا ودوت نت .. لكن إختيار جافا كلغة أساسية كان إختيار أندرويد
Mohamed Elsherif Java has events, it depends on the OS. JAVA SE has events (C# delegates) for swing environments. AFAIR, Java also has anonymous delegates like C# thru Java interfaces.

One more thing you will notice, which makes the Android API's less elegant, is the extensive use of constants where usually you would use Enums. and that's also because the Java Enums are just signleton instances of objects, so the extensive use of them hurt performance.
Java doesn't have events, usually they use single method interfaces to simulate events
they also don't have delegates, they have inline implementations of interfaces with anonymous classes to simulate delegates

"Hardware" Firing events is OS dependant. For example, in Android they fire events for touch screen events, in desktop, mouse events are too events.An most of those events the driver control it, and the OS get those events via interrupts or polling or whatever the method, all of that depends on the OS Layer, not the language capability.  If you mean by an event as a callback or C function pointers, or C# delegate,  then there is no problem if Java "simulate" it by interface or anything as long as they do the purpose. I believe that C# delegate keyword is just an abstraction for a lot of thing behind the scenes.

All what we are talking about is just how small changes in syntax can make things look better, properties are just a thin layer above set\get methods, but they make it easy to differentiate between regular methods and properties of a certain objects, same for events, they offer you the publish\subscribe separation without you needing to worry about how you should implement it.
To add to that, properties and events in .NET add abilities like applying some logic before storing values, and adding multiple handlers for the same event. It's harder to do that in Java.
I'm not for or against any language. I just like to understand the abilities and shortcomings of each one.
Use Xamarin Studio for Android
Looks like it's gonna be that, but I still have to support our product's API for Android :(
I'm digging in Phonegap. I like the idea of making once and deploying for multiple devices.
